p: To verify whether the synthesis rendered Nb 2O 5 nanorods, the Nb 2O 5 material was examined by using high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF)-STEM ( Figure 2). The HAADF-STEM images show that the hydrothermal synthesis produced Nb 2O 5 nanorods with approximately 8–25 nm length and 3–4 nm width ( Leal et al., 2019). The nanorod dimensions are in line with those of previous studies showing that the crystal growth in the hydrothermal method follows an oriented attachment mechanism ( Leite et al., 2006), producing nanorods smaller than those synthesized in the presence of a surfactant as a shape-directing agent. In fact, surfactant-based syntheses yield large particles, owing to a decrease in the rate of crystal growth ( Zhao et al., 2012a). In turn, longer (200–500 nm) and thinner (5–20 nm) TT-Nb 2O 2 nanorods were produced by a synthesis employing oleic acid as a structure-directing agent and ammonium niobium oxalate hydrate as the starting material ( Zhao et al., 2012b).
